title: Leyden Jar
text: Speed matters. The slower you rub the tube with the fur, the shock will be much bigger. Why does this happen?I think that if it is rubbed slowly there are more crackles and crackles = static electricity.I used the leyden jar to power a light bulb but it work. My theory is that it didn't work because rubbing a tube and some fur isn't as strong as a battery. I thought it would work because rubbing the tube and the fur would create static electricity and the sucks the power in to move the wire. And when you touch it, it's like an escape to the light which lights it up. But I don't understand why it didn't work a little.I think that the leyden jar holds electricity so when you rub the tube with fur close to the nail, the nail picks up electricity and when you touch it you get a shock.The slower you rub it the bigger the shock. I think that happens because more electricity rushes to the top and into the nail. title: Our problems and plans
text: Our problems:1. Why are there protons and neutrons in the nucleus? Do they need to be there?2. Are there other types of charges that we do not know about?3. What is light? Where does it come from? Why does a static shock create light?4. Do atoms contain energy? How dod they do it? How does an atomic bomb work?5. Can atoms and their electrons be created or destroyed? How can we do this?6. How do magnets work? Why do they throw compasses off?7. What are electrons made out of? Is there something smaller?What we need to do ...1. Invite a scientist to come and speak about atoms.2. We should dissect a battery and try to use the insides to power different objects.3. We should cut a magnet open to see if it still works.4. We should look deeper into how light works. What is it? How does it function?5. Experiment with different types of metals. Which one is more magnetic.6. What is the connection between magnets and electricity?

title: Quarks, and other particles
text: We tried to make fire with a flashlight through a magnifing glasses but it didn't work because you need solar power.- Atoms can be divided into smaller particles.- Protons and neutrons can be seperated from each other. Also they are made of smaller particles which is called quarks.- You can make atoms smaller by exploding them.- Only electrons cannot be splitted.- Neutrons are made of two down quarks and one up quarks.- Up quarks have a charge of +2/3.- A proton is two thousands times heavier than an electron. Neutrons are 1,839 times heavier than one electron.- Down quarks are the second lightest, the first lightest is up quarks.- Down quarks are fermions, which mean no two of them can not be in the same space at the same time.- Up quarks are so small that scientists believe they can not be divided any more.
